key_points: The Technical Advisory Group on SARS-CoV-2 Virus Evolution (TAG-VE) convened on 26 November 2021 to assess the B.1.1.529 variant.
B.1.1.529 variant was first reported by South Africa to WHO on 24 November 2021, with the first known infection from 9 November 2021.
The variant has a large number of mutations and preliminary evidence suggests an increased risk of reinfection.
B.1.1.529 cases are increasing in almost all provinces in South Africa.
Current SARS-CoV-2 PCR diagnostics can detect this variant; the S gene target failure in one PCR test can serve as a marker for this variant.
Based on the evidence, TAG-VE advised that B.1.1.529 should be designated as a Variant of Concern (VOC), named Omicron.
WHO has communicated the designation of Omicron as a VOC and will continue to update on new findings.
Countries are requested to enhance surveillance, sequencing, and report cases associated with VOC infection.
Individuals are reminded to continue adhering to public health measures and get vaccinated.
Definitions for SARS-CoV-2 Variant of Interest (VOI) and Variant of Concern (VOC) were reiterated.
